docs.text: capsule : a ham-handed and over/underwritten morality play masquerading as entertainment , so muddled it doesn't even know what it's really advocating , if anything .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: a time to kill has been hailed as the best of the grisham adaptations , and it's easy to see why : it presents a strong , almost rancorously so , story ; it is full of good actors ( samuel l . jackson , matthew mcconaughey , sandra bullock , kevin spacey , charles dutton ) ; and it's ostensibly about some important social issue that we're all tangling with .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it is not , however , a good movie , and all of the reasons i've listed above have something to do with why .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: right from the beginning , the movie is dead-set on stacking its deck as thoroughly and unrepentantly as possible .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: a pair of redneck whites , boozed and drugged out of their minds , kidnap a young black girl , abuse and rape her horribly , and leave her for dead .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: after their arrest , their father ( jackson ) takes an assault rifle and guns them down on the way to trial .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: mcconaughey is then drafted in as his lawyer , and the rest is somehow strangely predictable courtoom movie dramatics .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the acting is not quite what it should be , given the cast we have .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: sandra bullock ( who is a good actress but not a serious one ) looks clueless ; spacey's accent switches itself on and off at random ( and he's given a totally thankless role to play as well , a role without an iota of depth ) ; and mcconaughey's role is stamped from the cardboard back of a cereal box .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the most memorable role is donald sutherland's , and his is a bit part .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i always consider it an index of a movie's desperation when it is able to present shocking and outlandish events , and somehow not have them generate an ounce of impact .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there is one scene -- a riot outside the courtroom -- that should have created incredible tension , but winds up playing out like a textbook exercise on how not to deploy a scene like this .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: because the movie doesn't know what it's really about , it * can't * generate any genuine tension , and so it has to artifically inject tension through clumsy plotting .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: one of the ways it does this is by throwing in a whole subplot about a bunch of vicious kkk cross-burners -- which is tidied up so neatly that it borders on the nihilistic .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i was reminded of the despicable betrayed , which tried to tart up a fundamentally empty story by injecting vile , graphic acts of racism as little more than an attention-getter .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the movie immolates an enormous amount of its potential by making a few critical mistakes .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: first of all , the jackson character is not hard to judge ; there's no tension in his dilemma .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: he's self-admittedly guilty and should be sent to jail , no matter how moral his crusade .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the old saw about how no court in the land would convict him , if he was white , is supposed to be the underlying theme of the movie , but it's never developed into an organic component of the story .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it just sort of floats around on top while the movie grinds away furiously with its plot mechanics .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: another mistake is in motivational logic : by not having the two white thugs arraigned first -- or maybe tried and then dismissed from lack of evidence , say -- we have that much less empathy for jackson's character .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i'm probably supposed to think that just because he had his daughter raped , we are * automatically * supposed to feel empathy for him , but that's precisely the kind of facile thinking that makes real justice impossible .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: ( see the virgin spring for more on that note . )
docs.label: negative

docs.text: is jackson's character then simply insane ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: that prospect isn't given terribly serious treatment either .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: one of the most aggravating things about coutroom movies is how little they seem to know about how the law works , or how lawyers get their information .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: mcconaughey's character makes an important slipup late in the movie , when one of his witnesses turns out to have been convicted of a capital offense .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: how did the prosecution get this information ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: how come he didn't get it ?
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the whole way these questions get handled are symptomatic of the movie's way of dealing with complex legal and moral questions in cheap screenwriterly slam-bang fashion .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this is the biggest problem : the movie isn't about jackson's character , or his dilemma , or this case , or any of its ( frequently interesting despite the porcine writing and direction ) characters .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's not ultimately about anything at all , except its stupid geared-down plot , which inches onwards in one unremarkable scene after another towards a totally contrived ending .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: at two and a half hours , the movie is overlong and drastically overwritten : there's endless stuff about things which ultimately add up to nothing , and no writing about the material that should really matter .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's all handwaving .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the closing argument are also sneaky and underhanded , and underscored my suspicion that the movie is manipulative and unfair .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's not easy to make a movie about something .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the other day i saw kurosawa's phenomenal rashomon , a movie that is really about the way people deal with truth and reality ( or don't ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: a time to kill is as empty and ponderous a movie as i've seen in a long time .
docs.label: negative
